Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Gradient-augmented level set methods and jet schemes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on high-order generalizations of semi-Lagrangian approaches, called jet schemes (in the context of the transport of field quantities), and the gradient-augmented level set method (GALSM, in the context of interface tracking). These numerical methods achieve high-order of accuracy by tracking certain derivatives of the solution along characteristics. They are optimally local, in the sense that the data used to update the solution at a grid point is located only in a single grid cell, independent of the scheme's order. Moreover, the use of cell-based Hermite interpolations yields a certain level of subgrid resolution, which allows the GALSM to capture structures smaller than the grid resolution. The research in this project focuses on the numerical analysis and parallel performance of the new approaches, as well as their combination with adaptive mesh refinement and with Lagrangian particles. In addition, jet schemes are applied to kinetic equations, and the GALSM is applied to Hamilton-Jacobi equations. The latter results in the introduction of limiters, and provides a path to gradient-augmented re-initialization.

The accurate detection, tracking, and computation of interfaces (curves and surfaces) is an important problem in many areas of science and technology, such as: gas-liquid interfaces in computational fluid dynamics, phase transitions in materials, weather fronts, the motion of biological membranes, edge detection in medical imaging, flame fronts, and shock fronts in supersonic flows. The methods developed in this project allow the computational tracking of interfaces, as well as the evolution of field quantities, with high accuracy. At the same time, they are computationally efficient and very modular. Moreover, they are advantageous for the capture of small structures. This project involves an international collaboration, as well as the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has contributed new computational, and analytical, approaches for problems motivated by fluid dynamics applications. In addition: (1) Models describing the behavior of walking/bouncing fluid drops were developed and analyzed. (2) Simplified models for shocks in reacting media were developed and analyzed.

The Intellectual Merit of this research lies in (a) A geometrical understanding of the mechanism for the phenomena or order reduction for the time evolution, within the context of numerically solving partial differential equations. (b) Development of the concept of "weak stage order", which allows for the development of time evolution algorithms that do not exhibit order reduction. (c) Development of a new approach to characterize the unconditional stability problem for linear multi-step implicit-explicit time evolution schemes. Unconditional stability is a desirable property of a time stepping scheme, as it allows the choice of time step solely based on accuracy considerations. (d) A new class of high order linear multi-step implicit explicit schemes with large regions of unconditional stability was introduced. (e) Development of a fast and accurate algorithm for the solution of the Poisson equation with interfaces across which the solutions have jumps. Problem of this type arise when solving for the pressure in multi-phase flows, as well as when solving for both the pressure and the flow velocity in micro-fluidic problems across interfaces where the fluid properties change. (f) Numerical analysis of jet schemes: understanding of methods via long-wave limit and modified equation. Extension of the jet scheme methodology to problems that include a small amount of diffusion, and development of gradient-augmented limiters. (g) fundamental insights into the energy/information propagation direction for wave problems with damping. This leads to spectral basis of solutions that can be used for spectrally accurate computations in these settings [work still in progress]. (g) Study of the instabilities that arise for shock waves in reacting media. This includes the development, as well as the analysis and numerical study, of simplified models for the behavior. (h) Development of mathematical models for walking/bouncing fluid drops.

The Broader Impacts stem from the fact that accurate fluid flow, and/or wave propagation, computations are of crucial importance in many applications in science and engineering, including airplane wings, motor vehicles, and atmospheric/ocean flows, as well as the simulation of micro-fluidic flows. The theoretical aspects of this research provide new perspectives on the sources of errors, as well as possible remedies. A better understanding of the complex dynamics of reacting shock waves has implications for applications involving combustion. Finally, simplified mathematical models have pedagogical value as tools to introduce students to complex physical and mathematical phenomena in a context where understanding is easier. This project involved national and international collaborations, and the training of seven graduate students and five postdoctoral researcher.
